snippet: The government wants to lower the minimum age at which a court may restrict a person’s movement or communications.
abstract: Australian government proposes lowering minimum age threshold for so-called control orders, antiterrorism measure allowing courts to restrict person’s movements or communications, from 16 to 14; proposal is announced less than two weeks after 15-year-old  Farhad Jabar Khalil Mohammad shot and killed police accountant Curtis Cheng in Sydney.
lead_paragraph: The government wants to lower the minimum age at which a court may restrict a person’s movement or communications.

headline.print_headline: Australia Seeks Lower Age Threshold for Antiterror Controls
headline.main: Australia Seeks Lower Age Threshold for Antiterror Controls
